content.description: Start on the stain but instead of breaking left at the 3rd bolt break right and pull some steep moves bringing you to the right side of the roof, pull that to the anchors.

You can probably get away with no gear on this short and fun climb.  There are two distinct hard sections with a good shake out in the middle.

Start in a shallow left facing dihedral just to the left of the big roof routes on the lower wall.  Look for a pin in the corner that starts the route.  Clip the pin, plug pro or don't (sling long), make moves to gain the good hands above the small roof to clip the bolt.  Surmount the roof to gain the juggy face above.  Move up the steep face clipping two more bolts and move right below the roof to the anchors.
content.protection: 1 pin and some bolts.  Bring some longer draws to keep it running smooth.  A 60m is all you need to get down from the two-bolt anchor.

content.description:
The big tough roof!

Gain the starting ledge and clip the first bolt.  Climb through sustained slopers and crimps on the technical face to get established below the roof.  Make the tough and scary clip under the roof.  Don't blow this clip or you might slam the ledge below.  Explode to the lip of the roof and make another big committing move to gain the often wet and dirty ledge above.  Mantel onto the ledge and place some gear to protect the second during the crux.  Clip the bolt out left or move right into the Stain's upper face.  Climb either face to their respective anchors.
content.protection: 3 bolts and a single rack.  Some long runners will help.  Two bolt anchor at the top.  A 60m or smaller will get you down.
content.location: This is just left of the Stain under a large roof.  Look for chalked up holds directly below a roof with a bolt underneath it.

content.description:
This is the first climb on the upper section of Sunken Treasure.  Hike past the lower section and climb up the short gully to reach these routes.

Look for a bolt 20' up on the face just right of an arete.  Climb up the face, plug some pro.  Ride the arete to that first high bolt.  Move up to the ramp and plug some gear out right.  Start the funky and exciting traverse out right to gain the bolts around the upper arete.
content.protection: 1 bolt, long runners, and a single rack.  Two bolt anchor at the top will get you down with a 60m.

content.description:
An area classic and probably one of the best routes on both of the walls.

Start inside the big dihedral.  Get some high jugs to get onto the ledge above.  Plug some gear to get up to the first bolt under the roof.  Start the sustained and tricky crux below the roof.  Continue up and left to next dihedral and get some more gear before reaching the final bolt to the anchors.  This will keep your attention from the first bolt to the finish.
content.protection: 4 bolts, long runners, and a single rack from medium to big hands size.  A 60m rope will get you down from the two bolt anchors just below the top.

content.description:
A wall classic.  Bring some crimp strength, endurance, and good footwork for this short punchy route.

Mantle up onto the starting ledge.  Start crimping up the brown streak and beautiful little mail slots.  Clip the bolt and start the sustained crux.  Move up to the next bolt and make the final difficult move onto the ledge.  Plug some gear and continue moving up and right up a short blocky dihedral to the anchors.
content.protection: Two bolts protect the first 25', a rack of tri-cams or some medium sized cams is all that is needed for the top.  Rap from the two bolt anchor just below the top.  A 60m will easily get you down.
content.location: This is the obvious brown streak right in center of the lower wall.  A heads up start to the first bolt.

content.description: Climb through a vegetated corner and onto some ledges, following the crack, then move right onto the face. Pull the lip and anchor off of a cable on the tree.
content.location: Furthest to the left on the first block.

content.description: Good line. Easier than sailing shoes. Tackle sailing direct and mantle through the roof.
content.location: Bolted line just left of sailing shoes

content.description:
This is the first route you see when you reach the wall.  It is a nice little trad line that will eat up gear from start to finish.  Great warmup or route for the budding trad leader.

Start just below a left facing corner capped by a roof.  Make the difficult start to reach the corner.  Trend up and left on the slab until the corner goes vertical.  Make the short move up then traverse hard left to the anchors on Swashbuckler or continue to the top and walk-off.
content.protection: Single rack, tri-cams can help, and long runners to keep it clean.  Two bolts with rap rings to get down.  60m is all you need.

content.description: A decent line, nice and moderate with plenty of protection. Very gently overhanging, mount the block at the base using the popcorn flake and a few horizontal rails. Pass a bolt on a small arete, and head up through an overhanging juggy corner.
content.protection:
We used a lot of big stuff. Don't need to sling very long, the line is quite straight.

Bolted anchors.
content.location: The farthest left route at Sunken. Look for the lone bolt 30 feet up.

content.description: Direct start to Fat Man. A bouldery start leads to much easier climbing.
content.protection: Single rack. Two bolt anchor if you finish left, no anchor if you finish right.
content.location: Starts in the dihedral 20 ft left of the start of Fat Man

content.description:
This is the thin beautiful crack at the far left side of the lower wall.

This is one of the few routes that requires some specialized gear.  Bring a set of brass or ballnutz to protect the start in the thin crack.  This crack looks to have eaten a purple TCU.  Booty if you can get it!  Enjoy the slab up the thin crack, then move left to a bolt.  Pull up to the steepness to a short crack, the leftmost of the two.  Plug some gear in the crack and pull up onto the slab.  Get into the short corner and reach the tree just above with cable anchor and slings.
content.protection: Thin to medium sized gear.  Some long runners to extend the tree anchor over the ledge.  The rappel cable looks to be in good shape, but bring extra webbing if you doubt it.  The cable has two quick links to get down.  A 60m or less will be fine.
